stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on implementing a major visual and geometric rework of Course 10, provided by artist Biobak. The stream focused on integrating new assets like a new Yoshi model and foliage, debugging the associated technical issues (vertex painting, collision, animation), and beginning the process of creating a new collision map for the heavily modified level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is focused on deep engine optimization, including achieving zero compiler warnings and reordering actors in the level to improve instruction cache performance.
development_findings.quote: I am slowly approaching zero engine bugs. I actually got my entire compiler down to zero warnings as well.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's optimization efforts have resulted in Mario's core code loop remaining constantly in the instruction cache, a significant performance achievement he discovered through testing.
development_findings.quote: My game by itself is already so optimized that Mario's behavior loop never gets thrown out of cache which is fucking crazy.

development_findings.summary: Kaze explains that the game uses vertex colors to bake static lighting into level geometry. He identifies this as a 'strictly superior technique' for the N64, trading dynamic lighting effects for better performance and visual control.
development_findings.quote: The disadvantage is, you see, like, if Mario right here goes close to fire, how he, like, lights up slightly, you lose that effect. You can't multiply with shade color anymore. But for static level geometry like this, we can just bake the lighting right away.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged multiple issues with a new Yoshi model, including incorrect vertex painting in a new version of Blender, missing collision, and a clipped mouth animation.
A floor hazard was redesigned from a collapsing platform to one that slides into the wall, indicated by scratch marks on the floor. Kaze worked on implementing this new behavior.

Kaze encountered several rendering discrepancies between the Fast64 plugin and the in-game engine, particularly with alpha blending and color intensity, requiring him to debug visuals directly on hardware/emulator.
The project is using a newer C compiler than the original Mario 64, which allows for more modern syntax like declaring variables inside switch cases.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds strong, pragmatic, and sometimes provocative philosophies on software development, prioritizing low-level optimization (like manual cache management) over modern abstractions like Entity Component Systems, which he calls 'complete garbage'.
context_findings.quote: I only know as much C as I need to know to manipulate the compiler to get me the assembly instructions I need. Anything after that is mental illness.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses immense pride and confidence in the game's visual quality, believing it surpasses any other N64 title. He is emotionally invested in the project's technical and artistic achievements.
context_findings.quote: I don't think you can even make the case that there's a better looking N64 game than this like anywhere in the world. I think it's just untrue.

context_findings.summary: Kaze announced a new merch store on TeePublic, starting with a shirt for Course 4, with plans to create a design for every course in the final game.
Kaze announced that F3 2025, a game development event, will be sponsored and feature a user vote where the most popular game receives a cash prize upon release.
Kaze mentions that he works in the basement, a space designated by his wife, Zeina. This highlights the blend of their personal and professional lives.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a significant rework for Course 10, including a new Yoshi model, updated level geometry, bushes, and a redesigned sliding floor mechanism.

Kaze's workflow involves integrating Biobak's assets, then debugging and adapting them on the fly to fit the engine's technical constraints, such as fixing vertex color issues or N64-specific Z-clipping.
biobak.quote: What's wrong with the old Yoshi version anyway? Biobak made a nice out of it one. That's what's wrong with it.

biobak.summary: Biobak's asset delivery included a changelog, suggesting a structured, if not entirely formal, handoff process between him and Kaze.

zeina.summary: Zeina had a brief, lighthearted interaction with Kaze on stream about the definition of a hot dog, showcasing their casual dynamic.

key_stories.title: Integrating the New Yoshi Model
key_stories.summary: Kaze integrated a new Yoshi model from Biobak, navigating a series of technical hurdles from Blender version incompatibilities to in-game collision and animation bugs. The process demonstrates the iterative cycle of receiving assets, debugging technical issues, and making pragmatic decisions on which bugs to fix immediately.
key_stories.challenge: A new, higher-quality Yoshi model from Biobak needed to be integrated into the game, but it was incompatible with the current tools and engine setup.
key_stories.process: Kaze imported the model and immediately faced issues with vertex painting due to a new version of Blender. He painstakingly re-rigged the model, then discovered it was missing collision. After fixing that, he found an animation bug causing the mouth to clip and a separate bug making Yoshi talk twice. He debugged each issue sequentially, explaining his process.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully imported the model and fixed the visual and collision issues. However, a persistent bug causing Yoshi to deliver dialogue twice remains, which he decided to postpone fixing to maintain momentum.
key_stories.key_quote: What's wrong with the old Yoshi version anyway? Biobak made a nice out of it one. That's what's wrong with it.

key_stories.title: Creating Varied Foliage
key_stories.summary: When implementing new bush assets from Biobak, Kaze went through a detailed creative and technical process. He chose to add programmatic color and brightness variation to avoid visual monotony, demonstrating his philosophy of using simple technical tricks to enhance artistic output.
key_stories.challenge: Biobak provided new bush assets for Course 10, and Kaze needed to implement them in a way that was visually interesting and performed well.
key_stories.process: Kaze first decided against Biobak's suggestion of a uniform color, opting to use his existing primitive color multiplier for variation. He then adjusted the base colors to be greener, added programmatic brightness variance, fixed an issue with black outlines, and adjusted their vertical position to better suit the animation.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented the bushes with randomized color and brightness, creating a varied and aesthetically pleasing effect that he was proud of.
key_stories.key_quote: If you add all the colours, you just get cloud vomit... Yeah, this is very pretty if you ask me.

open_questions.context: Kaze integrates assets from Biobak, then debugs and modifies them live on stream. The feedback loop appears to be one-way during the stream (Biobak provides assets, Kaze fixes).
questions: Can you walk me through your typical collaborative workflow with Biobak? How do you two handle the hand-off of assets?
How do you communicate feedback or technical limitations back to him? Is it through Discord, changelogs, or live calls?
How did the decision to do a complete visual rework of Course 10 come about between you and Biobak?

open_questions.context: Kaze speaks with great passion and conviction about his low-level optimization techniques, such as managing the instruction cache directly and his dismissal of patterns like Entity Component Systems (ECS).
questions: You have a very distinct philosophy on engine optimization. Where does this passion for low-level control come from?
Was there a specific project or problem in your past that solidified this belief that manual cache management is superior to other patterns?
How do you balance the performance gains of these techniques with the potential complexity or difficulty for others who might work on the code?

open_questions.context: Kaze encounters a bug where Yoshi speaks twice. He investigates briefly, forms a hypothesis about the cause (a change to the object list or a flag), but ultimately decides to move on without fixing it.
questions: When you encounter a bug like the 'Yoshi talks twice' issue, what's your mental checklist for deciding whether to fix it now or shelve it for later?
Can you walk me through your debugging process for that specific issue? What did you suspect, and what would your next steps have been if you'd continued?
How much of your development time is spent on these kinds of emergent, unexpected bugs versus planned feature development?

open_questions.context: Kaze announced that the F3 2025 event will be sponsored and include a cash prize for the fan-voted winner.
questions: What was the process for securing a sponsorship for F3 2025?
What are your ultimate goals for the F3 event, and how do you think adding a cash prize will change the dynamic for participants?
How do you see this event contributing to the broader ROM hacking and indie development community?

open_questions.context: A floor hazard was redesigned from a simple collapse to a more complex sliding mechanism, prompted by a new asset from Biobak that included scratch marks on the floor.
questions: What was the design conversation with Biobak that led to changing the collapsing floor to a sliding one?
What gameplay problem or creative opportunity did this new design solve or introduce?
Can you describe the technical implementation of making the floor slide and interact with Mario correctly?
